Nāmakaokapāo‘o represents an older order, associated with darkness, the ocean depths (specifically *Nāmaka*, a sea goddess), and potentially destructive forces.  Puali‘i's act of consuming Nāmakaokapāo‘o is symbolic of the new generation overcoming and absorbing the power of the old, allowing for continued creation. This isn’t necessarily “evil” overcoming “good,” but rather a necessary cycle of renewal and transformation.
*   **Cannibalism & Mana:** The intent to consume Nāmakaokapāo‘o is significant. In Hawaiian belief, consuming another being (especially a powerful one) was a way to absorb their *mana* – spiritual power. This wasn’t simply about physical sustenance; it was a way to gain strength, knowledge, and authority. The act of eating the head specifically would transfer intelligence and leadership qualities.
*   **The Importance of Genealogy (Mo‘oku‘āhuna):** The reference to Nākukui‘aimakaokalani is vital. This name links Nāmakaokapāo‘o to a specific lineage and ancestor, reinforcing his power and status. Hawaiian society was deeply rooted in genealogy; knowing one’s ancestors (and being able to recite them) was essential for establishing legitimacy and claiming authority. The invocation of ancestors also provided spiritual protection.
*   **Death Prayer (Pule Make):** Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s response is not defiance, but a death prayer directed *at Puali‘i*. This highlights the power of Hawaiian chants (*oli*) and prayers.  Chants weren’t simply poetic expressions; they were believed to have the power to influence reality. The prayer is a plea for acceptance of fate, invoking ancestors and appealing to the natural world.
*   **Ali‘i Nui & Political Power:** The description of Nāmakaokai‘a as *ali‘i nui* (great chief) is important. This connects the mythological realm to the earthly political structure of Hawai‘i. *   **Understanding Hawaiian Worldview:** This passage provides valuable insights into the Hawaiian worldview, which emphasized interconnectedness, respect for ancestors, and the cyclical nature of life and death.

He is frequently linked to the sky father, Kāne, and represents a primal force in island formation. He's not simply a chief ("aliʻi nui") but a foundational deity. The relationship between father and son is crucial; it establishes a direct lineage within the volcanic forces of the island.  The "aliʻi nui" designation here is less about political power and more about divine authority.

The pairing of these names – “Eyes to the Heavens” and “Eyes to the Sea” – is symbolic. reference_commentary: **Paragraph 9:**• While the abandonment of the ‘Ai Kapu and the rise  of Christianity are historical, Pua-li‘i’s attack of Nā- maka-o-ka-pāo‘o does not seem to have a correlating  historical reference. The ‘Ai Kapu was abandoned in  1819 and the first Christian missionaries arrived in  Hawai‘i in 1820, with a full year in the interum of no  organized religion to replace the ‘Ai Kapu. While  many Hawaiians were stubbon to adopt Christianity  and resented it, Christianity spread quickly and  overwhelmed any pro-‘Ai Kapu sentiment by the end  of the 1820s. If Pua-li‘i here represents the ‘Ai Kapu  and Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o represents Christianity, and  the adoption of Western culture in a more broad  sense, this event in the story seems to misrepresent  the ‘Ai Kapu as savage, impulsive, and violent against  Christianity, culminating in a single event. There is no  such historical single event recorded in history;  • By a twist of fate, the adze Pua-li‘i wielded to cut off  the head of Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o somehow turned  against the wielder, cutting off the head of Pua-li‘i,  which Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o tossed into the ocean at Wai-pouli (water of darkness), a cave in Hono-uliuli  (bay of darkness) in ‘Ewa, O‘ahu, a distance of five   miles away. This ironic demise of Pua-li‘i signifies the  ultimate defeat of the ‘Ai Kapu by Christianity and/or  progressive ambitions, but this violent event has no  parallel in Hawaiian history. This could be viewed as  an embellishment as a type of Christian progaganda.  • The five-mile long toss of Pua-li‘i’s head by  Nāmakaokapāo‘o was an emphasis on the boy’s  superhuman physical strength.

gemma-3-27b-it-qat-mlx-maui_translation: Puali‘i was made (or born), returned to Nāmakaokapāo‘o, reaching his mother, Pōka‘ī. They resided together, but Nāmakaokapāo‘o did not eat food. At that time, ‘Ama‘u was a chief of O‘ahu, residing in Waikīkī where he lived. A man from Honouliuli came to Waikīkī, reaching the chief’s residence. He said: “O Chief! There is a very small but incredibly strong boy, his father has died and his head was thrown into the sea – a very long distance, five miles in length. And ‘Ama‘u heard this; his strength lies within him and I will die to him, but if I do not die to him he has no strength.” While he was speaking in Waikīkī, Nāmakaokapāo‘o heard these words concerning him.

At that  time, ‘Ama‘u was a chief of O‘ahu in Waikīkī,  where he lived. A man of Honouliuli came to Waikīkī, where the chief was found. The man said,  “Chief, there is a little boy who is amazingly strong.  He killed his father and threw his head in the  ocean a really long distance away, five miles off.”  When ‘Ama‘u heard this, he said, “We’ll see how  strong he is if he kills me. gemma-3-27b-it-qat-mlx-maui_translation: Then, he took his mother and hid her in the cave of Waipouli. When the mother disappeared, he returned to their house at Keahumoa and sat down. Nāmakaokapāo'o climbed up onto the roof of the house, opened the openings on the back and front sides, and lay down between them directly above the roof ridge.

hawaiian_text: Ho'ouna maila 'o 'Ama'u ke ali'i mai Waikīkī mai, 'ehā po'e kaua, aia ma ka po'e ho'okahi he kanahā kumamāwalu kānaka ka nui, pēlā ā pau nā po'e 'ehā. A hiki lākou ma ke kula o Keahumoa, komo lākou ā loko o ka hale, 'a'ohe kanaka. A mākaukau lākou e ho'i, kāhea mai 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o i luna o kaupoku. A lohe lākou i ka leo, 'a'ohe na'e he 'ike 'ia o ke kino, nīnau aku lākou: "'Auhea 'oe e wala'au nei?" 'Ī mai 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o: "Eia nō wau i luna nei." Pi'i a'ela 'ewalu kānaka, 'ehā ma ke kua o ka hale, 'ehā ma ke alo o ka hale ā loa'a 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o. 'Ī mai 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o: "He aha mai nei kā 'oukou o 'one'i?" 'Ī aku lākou: "I hele mai nei mākou e kaua me Nāmakaokapāo'o, he wahi keiki 'u'uku e like me 'oe, he ikaika a me ke koa loa, nāna nō i pepehi i kona makua kāne, 'o Puali'i."
gemma-3-27b-it-qat-mlx-maui_translation: 'Ama'u sent four warriors from Waikīkī. Each group numbered eighty people, the same for all four groups. When they arrived at the field of Keahumoa, they entered the house, but there was no one inside. As they were preparing to leave, Nāmakaokapāo'o called out from above the roof. They heard the voice, but could not see a body. They asked: "Where are you calling from?" Nāmakaokapāo'o replied: “I am here above.” Eight people climbed up, four to the back of the house and four to the front, and they found Nāmakaokapāo'o. Nāmakaokapāo'o said: “What is the purpose of your coming here?” They replied: "We have come to fight Nāmakaokapāo'o, a small child like you, who is so strong and brave, the one who killed his father, Puali'i."

reference_translation: Chief 'Ama'u sent four regiments of soldiers from Waikīkī totalling forty-eight men. When they reached the plains of Keahumoa, they entered the house, but no one was there. When they were ready to return back to Waikīkī, Nāmakaokapāo'o called out from on top of the roof. They heard the voice, but didn't see any body, and they asked, "Where is that voice coming from?" Nāmakaokapāo'o said, "I'm up here." Eight men climbed up, four men went onto the roof and four on the face of the house and got a hold of Nāmakaokapāo'o. Nāmakaokapāo'o said, "What in the world are you all doing here?" They said, "We came to fight Nāmakaokapāo'o, a little boy like you, who is really strong and brave. He killed his father, Puali'i."

gemma-3-27b-it-qat-mlx-maui_translation: Nāmakaokapāo'o spoke: "I know, I am a great person, Nāmakaokapāo'o, and I have been traveling in Koʻolau, and I am a name belonging to him." When they arrived down, Nāmakaokapāo'o was utterly defeated and completely killed, leaving only one person remaining. That was the one who went and found 'Ama'u in Waikīkī, who reported the death of them all, leaving him alone to hear it.

gemma-3-27b-it-qat-mlx-maui_translation: Hearing of 'Ama'u, he immediately prepared his eighteen war canoes and sailed down to 'Ewa to battle with Nāmakaokapāo'o. When 'Ama'u and his people arrived at 'Ewa, Nāmakaokapāo'o utterly destroyed everything; no one remained alive, and 'Ama'u died. O'ahu surrounded Nāmakaokapāo'o, and then she took her mother and placed her upon the land of O'ahu.
